subject: Re: [junit] How to automate the testcases!
messageBody:
> I was interested about the idea that JUnit might not be the best
> tool for testing negative test cases.

To make sure that we are talking about the same subject, I define 'negative
testing' as making sure that the software (library in our case) is not doing
what it is not supposed to do. In other words, that your system can handle
incorrect or inappropriate information. Examples are:

- calling a method with wrong arguments (null, boundaries...)
- wrong type of String (numeric instead of text, wrong date format...)
- partial initialization of members
- methods called in no particular order (may reveal unstable state)
- ...

the problem with negative testing is that it's endless. It's hard to test what
a system can do but even harder to test what it can't.

It's possible to use JUnit to write negative tests (like testing exceptions)
but if you have 1,000 classes and you want to test that each method of every
class handles 'null' arguments correctly... well it's going to take a while.

That's why I think that JUnit is not the best suited for heavy negative testing
but if you come with some kind of automated testing, I'll be more than happy to
change my mind :-)

Other opinions/feedback out there?

-Vladimir
